Question:
Having explained the perfection of patience, now the perfection of vigor should be explained.
Answer:
Vigor is the essence and characteristic of bravery, and the function of vigor, etc.

Among them, the bodhisattvas, from the initial arousal of the mind until the ultimate stage of enlightenment, establish all the wholesome actions of body, speech, and mind associated with the factors of enlightenment. This is called the perfection of vigor.
Moreover, if it is vigor that is not shared with ordinary beings, learners, arhats, pratyekabuddhas, etc., this is called the perfection of vigor.
There are three kinds of vigor, namely, physical, verbal, and mental.
Those physical and verbal vigors are preceded by mental vigor. In brief, there are three kinds of meritorious deeds.
If the body is associated with meritorious deeds, it is physical vigor.
If it is associated with speech, it is verbal effort.
If it is associated with mind, it is mental effort.
Moreover, in terms of benefiting oneself or benefiting others, physical effort is bodily effort.
Verbal effort is verbal effort, and mental effort is mental effort.
Furthermore, there are thirty-two kinds of bodhisattva effort, namely, effort in not cutting off the lineage of the Three Jewels;
effort in maturing immeasurable sentient beings;
effort in embracing immeasurable transmigration;
effort in making immeasurable offerings and service;
effort in accumulating immeasurable wholesome roots;
effort in producing immeasurable effort;
effort in speaking well to delight sentient beings;
effort in bringing peace and security to all sentient beings;ğŸ”½effort in doing what sentient beings should do;
effort in practicing equanimity among all sentient beings;
effort in receiving and studying all precepts;
effort in taming with the power of forbearance;
The effort of giving rise to various dhyÄnas, samÄdhis, and samÄpattis;
The effort of perfecting non-attached wisdom;
The effort of accomplishing the four kinds of brahmavihÄras;
The effort of giving rise to the five supernatural powers;
The effort of using the merits of all buddha-lands to perfect one's own buddha-land;
The effort of subduing mÄras;
The effort of subduing non-Buddhist teachers in accordance with the Dharma;
The effort of perfecting the ten powers, fearlessnesses, and other buddha-dharmas;
The effort of adorning body, speech, and mind;
The effort of attaining liberation from all that is to be done;
The effort of destroying afflictions;

The effort of liberating those who are not yet liberated, freeing those who are not yet freed, bringing solace to those who have not yet found solace, and bringing parinirvÄá¹‡a to those who have not yet attained parinirvÄá¹‡a;
The effort of accumulating the provisions of merit and virtue;
The effort of embracing all buddha-dharmas;
The effort of traveling to boundless buddha-lands;
The effort of seeing immeasurable buddhas.

This effort arises from great compassion, because it is free from body, speech, and mind, because it abides in non-grasping and non-abandoning, because it attains neither exaltation nor depression, and because it subsumes non-arising and non-production.
Having perfected these thirty-two dharmas, the perfection of effort will be attained and fulfilled.
Herein, there is also a holy verse:
Those perfections such as giving, are accomplished by the power of effort,
Therefore, effort is the fundamental, by which bodhisattvas attain the Buddha's body.
Effort and skillful means seek enlightenment, I think effort is the supreme skillful means,
Because, having abandoned effort, skillful means cannot accomplish what is to be done.
If there were only a single skillful means, then there would be no exertion to carry out activities,
All activities are done through effort, therefore effort is the supreme skillful means.
The mind has skillful power as a means, this mind arises from diligence,
Therefore, all the things that are done, are all based on diligence.
The various treatises and crafts, etc., by possessing diligence one reaches the other shore,
Therefore, among all the things that are done, diligence is the most accomplished one.
All the self-mastery and wealth, a diligent person is able to obtain,
Therefore, all the things that bring happiness, are all caused by diligence.
Because of having superior diligence, the Buddha is the foremost among the Å›rÄvakas,
Therefore, this power of diligence is the most superior cause, not other practices.
For the superior and valiant one with superior diligence, although the same as those on the stages,
He always obtains the most superior, therefore one should always arouse diligence.
When the Buddha was under the Bodhi tree, he attained enlightenment through diligence,
Therefore, diligence is the fundamental cause, and the cause for attaining the Buddha's body has been explained before.
Question:
Having briefly explained the perfection of diligence, now the perfection of meditation should be explained.
Answer:
Meditation has four types, namely, with initial and sustained thought, joy and happiness arising from separation, abiding in the first meditation;
without initial and sustained thought, concentration-born joy and happiness, abiding in the second meditation;
apart from joy, practicing equanimity, mindfulness and wisdom, experiencing happiness, abiding in the third meditation;

Among these four types of meditation, apart from realizing the stage of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and dedicating to the stage of Buddhahood, it is called the perfection of meditation.

Question:
The explanation of the perfection of meditation has been briefly concluded. Now, in sequence, the perfection of wisdom should be explained.
Answer:
As for the perfection of wisdom, it was explained earlier as part of the initial provisions.
I will now further explain its characteristics.
As stated in the previous verse:
Generosity, morality, patience, diligence, and meditation - the remainder of these five,
Those perfections are subsumed within the perfection of wisdom.
The remaining four perfections are the perfection of skillful means, the perfection of vows, the perfection of power, and the perfection of wisdom.
These four perfections are all included in the perfection of wisdom.
As for the perfection of wisdom, when the World-Honored Buddha, under the bodhi tree, with the wisdom of a single thought, realized all dharmas, this is the perfection of wisdom.
It is also the characteristic of non-obstruction, because it has no body.
It is the characteristic of boundlessness, because it is equal to space.
It is the characteristic of the unequaled, because all dharmas are unobtainable.
It is the characteristic of separation, because it is ultimately empty.
It is the characteristic of invincibility, because there is nothing to be obtained.
It is the characteristic of no phrases, because there are no names.
It is the characteristic of no aggregation, because it is apart from coming and going.
It is the characteristic of no cause, because it is apart from the creator.
It is the characteristic of no arising, because arising does not exist.
It is the characteristic of no going and coming, because it is apart from the turning of the wheel.
It has no characteristic of disintegration, because it is apart from the past and future.
It has no characteristic of defilement, because it cannot be grasped.
It has no characteristic of conceptual proliferation, because it is apart from all conceptual proliferation.
It has no characteristic of movement, because the dharma realm is its essence.
It has no characteristic of arising, because it does not discriminate.
It has no characteristic of measure, because it is apart from measure.
It has no characteristic of dependence, because dependence does not exist.
It has no characteristic of pollution, because it does not give rise to anything.
It has no characteristic that can be fathomed, because it has no bounds.
It has a natural characteristic, because it knows the intrinsic nature of all dharmas.

Having explained the perfection of skillful means, I will now explain the perfection of vows.
The bodhisattvas initially have ten great vows, namely: making offerings and attending to all Buddhas without remainder, this is the first great vow.
